channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Court of Appeal ruling paves way for changes in child abduction cases
item.description: There are set to be minor tweaks to how international child abduction cases are judged in New Zealand, after a ruling by the Court of Appeal.

item.title: Live: Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 4 June
item.description: Business leaders on both sides of the Tasman have issued a proposal to start flights between Wellington and Canberra in less than a month. For the latest, follow RNZ's live blog.

item.title: Air New Zealand customers should get choice of refund or credit, Consumer NZ says
item.description: The consumer watchdog says it is not reasonable for Air New Zealand to deny customers refunds and offer them credits instead. While one customer claims the credit system is too complex.

item.title: Level 1 move: social life dreams for some; worry for vulnerable
item.description: The future move to alert level 1 will see many breathe a sigh of relief at the return to normality, but there are fears it will put immunocompromised people in danger.

item.title: Speed and alcohol linked to fatal boat crash on Hollyford River - TAIC report
item.description: Speed and alcohol were factors in a fatal jet boat crash in Fiordland last year.

item.title: Risk of closures: Language schools plead for certainty over borders
item.description: English language schools are warning their $500 million industry is in a critical state because of dwindling student numbers.

item.title: Waitomo tourist attraction gets Covid-19 tourism recovery funding
item.description: Discover Waitomo and the country's 31 regional tourism organisations are the first to receive money from a government fund to help the sector recover from Covid-19 disruption.

item.title: Call for government to ban plastic drink bottles
item.description: Greenpeace is calling on the government to make New Zealand the first country in the world to ban plastic drink bottles.

item.title: Sarah Stuart-Black: New Zealand's voice during a disaster
item.description: Feature interview - When you see or hear from Sarah Stuart-Black it's usually because there's been a disaster. Political Reporter Jo Moir talked to her about her role in the response to Covid-19.

item.title: Sir Ben Ainslie presses case for America's Cup visas for UK team
item.description: The skipper of the UK's America's Cup sailing team says he may not be able to prepare properly if the crew can't secure exemption visas to travel to New Zealand soon.

item.title: Concern over DHBs' reluctance to use government's contact tracing system
item.description: Experts fear a future outbreak of Covid-19 could be harder to control because half of the country's DHBs are not using the government's national contact tracing system.

item.title: Why is Transmission Gully such a troubled project?
item.description: The Detail: It's proving complex to build a coastal bypass road north of Wellington. Transmission Gully has been in the planning stages for over a century - and it's hit more hiccups.

item.title: Manslaughter charges laid against three police officers in New Plymouth court
item.description: Police have filed charges of manslaughter against three officers over the death of a man in custody at the Hāwera Police Station last year.

item.title: Air NZ on non-refundable airfares: 'credits' over refund
item.description: Checkpoint - Air New Zealand says it cannot afford to offer refunds to everyone impacted by flight cancellations during the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Air India flights to bring Kiwis home - MFAT
item.description: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade is aware of a proposal for a private charter flight to get people stranded in India home, but says its focus is on a plan by the Indian authorities.

item.title: Government to provide free sanitary items in schools
item.description: The government is taking steps to tackle period poverty by providing free products in schools.

item.title: Quake-damaged Wellington Library to be repaired, council decides
item.description: Wellington councillors have made refitting and strengthening the existing library their preference, rather than building a new one.

item.title: Dunedin on the fast track to end slowdown
item.description: The Dunedin City Council will decide on Monday whether to end a controversial project designed to entice people back to the central city after the Covid-19 lockdown.
